newsitem.title: INDIA: South India state signs deals for six power plants.
newsitem.headline: South India state signs deals for six power plants.

text.p: India's southern state of Andhra Pradesh has signed agreements with six private power developers to set up a total of eight new power projects with a total capacity of over 1,600 MW, officials said on Tuesday.
Each of the firms setting up the projects is a joint venture with a foreign power company, the officials said.

The signing of the power purchase agreements (PPAs), which specify the terms under which the state-run electricity board will buy power from the private developers, had been delayed since July 1996, an official statement said.
"The PPAs have been concluded now," it added. It gave no reason for the delay.
The projects that received the final nod are to be built by the following joint venture partners:
Australia's Pacific Power International has tied up with India's Satyam Constructions to build a 300-MW naphtha-based power project at Peddapuram.
EPON of the Netherlands has tied up with Sew Constructions to build two 100-MW naptha-based projects, at Vemagiri and Samalkot.
The U.S.'s Niagara Mohawk Power Corp has tied up with India's Lanco Industries to build a 355-MW naphtha-based plant at Kondapally.
Singapore's Oakwell Engineering Ltd has tied up with the Malaysia Shipyard and Engineering to put up two barge-mounted naptha-based projects, each of 100 MW capacity at the port city of Kakinada.
The Tucson Electric Power Co. has tied up with Usha Martin Industries Ltd. to put up a 100-MW naphtha-based project at the port city of Vishakapatnam.
India's Ispat group has tied up with Japan's Nippon Denro to build a 468-MW naphtha-based project at Vemagiri.

The statement said global bids for these short-gestation projects had been invited by the state government in May 1995, and six offers of a total of 36 bids were selected, with letters of intent issued to the bidders.
